Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, the hum of my laptop blending with the distant toll of the convent bell. As an engineer, I was under pressure—my team and I needed to deliver a working prototype by the end of the week. The stakeholders were anxious, their emails growing more urgent, reminding me that our project’s future depended on this prototype. Every minute counted, and I felt the weight of their expectations pressing down on me.

But then, Sister Maria knocked gently on my door. “A family nearby lost their home to a fire last night,” she said softly. “They need food, clothing, comfort. We’re gathering supplies and going over to help.” As a nun, I was expected to serve, to be present for those in need, to embody compassion and charity. My heart ached for the family, imagining their fear and loss.

I stared at my screen, torn. The world demanded my skills and my spirit, both at once. I could not ignore the suffering outside, nor the responsibility inside. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which call to answer first.
